author: greg
title: Android SDK
description: Les développeurs mobiles qui veulent intégrer Cardano doivent construire leur propre réplique d'outils, ce qui nécessite des connaissances en cryptographie.

f6_assessments.q0:
There is not enough information on the feasibility of the proposal and how effectively it addresses the challenge in its entirety. 
It's recommendable a more understandable view of the proposed metrics and how the value can bring ROI and value to the entire Cardano ecosystem. Also, the proposer has not given any reference to any of his past work of a similar scale and there is no detailed project plan included in this proposal or attachments.
f6_assessments.q1: It is very hard to predict the success of a proposal without a way to track progress, and the information and samples provided give little confidence that the proposal will succeed.
f6_assessments.q2:
We should have an idea as to how the idea's of having an Android SDK leverage points are superior to those offered by other community members based on the plan. It is important to be aware of why the community would benefit from the idea. The reason should be clearly explained in this section of your plan.
It would be helpful to have a better understanding of the proposed metrics and how they could bring value and ROI to the entire Cardano ecosystem. Additionally, the proposer has not provided any references to his past work of similar scope, nor has a detailed project plan been attached to this proposal.
In the absence of a method to track progress, this becomes an extremely vague proposal, where the information and sample documents give little confidence that the proposal is viable.

f6_assessments.q0: Blockchain development is risky due to its vast scope in software implementation with cryptographic primitives. Therefore open source SDKs that can implement with third-party verification can be a great help to the ecosystem. Therefore this proposal is addressing the core challenge in the ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers claim 20 years of experience in software development, however, there are no references to substantiate the claim. Assuming that the proposers have the capability the proposal per se should be possible to complete with this assessment. SDKs can have a wide scope and the proposal has not presented a sharp feature set for the SDK therefore there is a need to finalize it.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal aims to develop an "SDK that would do all the cryptographic heavy lifting needed for interaction with the Cardano network so that Android engineers could focus on building user experience, lower the bar for many developers with great ideas and save time for those who cannot deal with the complexity of Cardano". This is not very specific and leaves scope for interpretation. However, the progress can be benchmarked since the proposal will develop the software in opensource and the same can be easily audited.  The fund requested is very reasonable.

f6_assessments.q0: The project wants to build tooling for android developers that abstract away the cardano library internals, to allow android developers to save time and focus on applications instead of technicalities.  This fits the challenge setting and If successful the impact would be great for the ecosystem since more Dapps are needed to drive adoption. The proposal identifies a problem that's relevanat, and should be worked on for sure. It's clear how the propsal will add value to the cardano ecosystem, by including android developers without any skills in crypto start to try to write Dapps. A little disapointing, but there are no KPIs or metrics introduced in the propsal. I hope the proposers have thought about scaling their solution, because if more people start using their tooling, I'm not sure if just two developers will be able to keep up. The proposal is lacking a detailed description. This would have greatly help me to understand the technical details and architecture of the proposed SDK. As an ex-android dev myself, I'dhave been happy to help. The ecosystem is missing an android sdk implementation and has to rely on javascript implementations which are not meant to be run on android.
f6_assessments.q1: Fragkiskos Katsimpas has only relevant experience in iOS development, which is very different than android, but he's a consultant now and I'm willing to believe that he has android experience even though not stated in his linked in. Unfortunately I couldn't find the other proposal "Greg" because of the lack of information and lack of links with credentials provided. In all honesty they say that they have software engineering experience and not android specific experience. There will be two members implementing the whole SDK which is definately possible, speaking as a dev myself. The budget is another point which is a bit lacking in the proposal. The budget is stated, but no breakdown of costs or hourly rates have been provided. There is not timeline stated for the completion of the project, nor a definition of success is given. The proposal says what it's going to do, but not when will it be finished or how it will be finished which is kind of disapointing. I would recommend to the proposers to do a technical document outlinging the planned out architecture so that it's a truly open source effort. The community wants to help, you just have to let it! The plan doesn't describe the resources necessary to implement the proposal which is not a big deal by itself, but combined with the other points it is.  There is no mention of possible risks concerning the implementation, usability or anything else, and when you're writing software you need to think of the worst case scenario as I'm sure the proposers are well aware.
f6_assessments.q2: There is no mention of a repository that will hold the code, so I'm not sure if it will be open source or not, but relying on the fact the proposal is in the Open Source challenge the proposal will be open source as well. If there isn't an open source repository I struggle to see if the community will be able to follow along with the implementation and progress of the project. As I mentioned there are no KPIs or metrics to speak of, so skipping this point. Every proposal needs to have a roadmap at least, keep that in mind for future proposals and I can advise you to take a look at other proposals to see what's considered common information. Alongside that you can take a look at the community generated documents specifiing the criteria for a proposal.   If the proposers put themselves in the shoes of the voter and look at their proposal, I think they'd realise they don't inspire much confidence.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is about creating a software development kit for Android. The problem statement [mobile devs who want to integrate Cardano, have to build their own replica of tools, which requires knowledge of cryptography] is quite clear and explained in detail. Conceptually, I think it has a certain fit for the challenge. However, It seems that this proposal is incomplete. The solution's direction is worth trying for completing in the following fund. Based on the given information, I disagree with this proposal's impact, and would give it a score of 2.
f6_assessments.q1: It's difficult to evaluate an incomplete proposal [information of experience and the team is too limited, doesn't have any roadmap or KPIs, and of course the risk is not defined]. This team with 02 engineers of 20+ years of combined experience is quite suitable for this kind of proposal, however, there is no proof/link for verification. As a result, definitely, there are no grounds to agree on the feasibility of this proposal, however, my only advice would be: in case it is necessary to complete this proposal in the next Catalysts in the future, the proposer should pay attention to ensure that the following components are fully met: (i) Goals and target; (2) road map (integrated with measurable KPIs/metrics); (3) Budget breakdown; (4) Risk and challenge. Based on the given information, I disagree with this proposal's feasible, and would give it a score of 2.
f6_assessments.q2: For an incomplete proposal like this, auditability / transparency can't be guaranteed. Therefore, I don't have much advice, except that: the proposer needs to ensure that the following components are fully met: (i) Goals and target; (2) road map (integrated with measurable KPIs/metrics); (3) Budget breakdown; (4) Risk and challenge. Based on the given information, I strongly disagree with this proposal's auditability, and would give it a score of 1.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposers wants to create a software development kitto lay a foundation for building mobile Cardano apps without knowing cryptographic internals. this falls well into the challenge setting that aims too support the development of tools needed for projects to make use of the cardano blockchain. This project will have a positve impact on the Catalyst Eco system.
f6_assessments.q1: No team members are named or set out with their credentials or links to anything to proof their existence and skills. The busget is not laid out at all. there is no Road map, timeline or actionable steps. Next time set out  and explain the budget, give a timeline and road map with actionable tasks and milestones.
f6_assessments.q2: There is no way to track progress of this project as there is no timeline, KPI's or road map set out. Next time set these out to be more successful. Also add experience of the team with links to their credentials.

experience: Deux ingénieurs avec plus de 20 ans d'expérience combinée acquise sur des projets de plusieurs millions de dollars.
